revision.text:
[[File:Spermathek Acanthoscurria geniculata.jpg|thumb|Spermatheca of ''[[Acanthoscurria geniculata]]'' (Brazilian Giant White Knee Tarantula)]] [[File:Parasite170028-fig20 Illustrated guide of Phlebotominae (Diptera, Psychodidae).png|thumb|Variety of the structure of spermathecae in [[Phlebotominae]] (Diptera, Psychodidae)]]
The '''spermatheca''' (pronounced {{IPAc-en|s|p|ɚ|m|ə|ˈ|θ|iː|k|ə}} plural: '''spermathecae''' {{IPAc-en|s|p|ɚ|m|ə|ˈ|θ|iː|s|iː}}), also called '''receptaculum seminis''' (plural: '''receptacula seminis'''), is an [[organ (biology)|organ]] of the female reproductive tract in [[insect]]s, e.g. [[bee]]s,<ref>Tales V. Pascini, and Gustavo F. Martins. 2017. "The insect spermatheca: an overview". ZOOLOGY https://doi.org/10.1016/j.zool.2016.12.001</ref> some [[mollusc]]s, [[oligochaeta]] worms and certain other [[invertebrate]]s and [[vertebrate]]s.<ref>David M. Sever, Cynthia K. Tait, Lowell V. Diller, and Laura Burkholder. 2004. ''Ultrastructure of the Annual Cycle of Female Sperm Storage in Spermathecae of the Torrent Salamander'' [[Rhyacotriton variegatus]] ''(Amphibia: Rhyacotritonidae)''. JOURNAL OF MORPHOLOGY 261:1–17</ref> Its purpose is to receive and [[female sperm storage|store sperm]] from the male or, in the case of [[hermaphrodites]], the male component of the body. Spermathecae can sometimes be the site of [[fertilisation|fertilization]] when the [[oocyte]]s are sufficiently developed.<ref>Jan A. Pechenick. Biology of the Invertebrates. New York: McGraw Hill, 2005</ref>
Some species of animal have multiple spermathecae. For example, certain species of earthworms have four pairs of spermathecae—one pair each in the 6th, 7th, 8th, and 9th segments. The spermathecae receive and store the spermatozoa of another earthworm during copulation.<ref>Jan A. Pechenik. Biology of the Invertebrates. New York: McGraw Hill, 2010, pg. 322</ref> They are lined with [[epithelium]] and are variable in shape: some are thin, heavily coiled tubes, while others are vague outpocketings from the main reproductive tract. It is one of the many variations in sexual reproduction.
The nematode ''[[Caenorhabditis elegans]]'' has two spermathecae, one at the end of each gonad.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = On the control of oocyte meiotic maturation and ovulation in Caenorhabditis elegans.|date = |journal = Dev. Biol.|doi = 10.1006/dbio.1998.9109|pmid = 9882501|access-date = |volume=205 |year=1999 |pages=111–28 | last1 = McCarter | first1 = J | last2 = Bartlett | first2 = B | last3 = Dang | first3 = T | last4 = Schedl | first4 = T}}</ref> The ''C. elegans'' spermatheca is made up of 24 smooth muscle-like cells that form a stretchable tubular structure.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wormatlas.org/hermaphrodite/somatic%20gonad/Images/somaticfig8leg.htm|title = WormAtlas|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> [[Microfilament|Actin filaments]] line the spermatheca in a circumferential manner. The ''C. elegans'' spermatheca is used as a model to study [[mechanotransduction]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title = FLN-1/Filamin is required for maintenance of actin and exit of fertilized oocytes from the spermatheca in C. elegans|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0012160610009899|journal = Developmental Biology|date = 2010-11-15|pmc = 2957521|pmid = 20707996|pages = 247–257|volume = 347|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.ydbio.2010.08.005|first = Ismar|last = Kovacevic|first2 = Erin J.|last2 = Cram}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Transient Membrane Localization of SPV-1 Drives Cyclical Actomyosin Contractions in the C. elegans Spermatheca|url = http://www.cell.com/article/S0960982214014948/abstract|journal = Current Biology|issn = 0960-9822|pmid = 25532891|pages = 141–151|volume = 25|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.cub.2014.11.033|first = Pei Yi|last = Tan|first2 = Ronen|last2 = Zaidel-Bar|year=2015}}</ref>
An [[beekeeping|apiculturist]] may examine the spermatheca of a dead [[queen bee]] to find out whether it had received [[sperm]] from a male.<ref name="glenn">{{cite web | url=http://www.glenn-apiaries.com/sperm.html | title=Diagnosis of failing queens by inspecting the spermatheca | accessdate=May 17, 2012}}</ref> In many species of stingless bees, especially [[Melipona bicolor]], the [[Queen bee|queen]] lays her eggs during the provisioning and oviposition process and the spermatheca fertilizes the egg as it passes along the [[oviduct]]. The [[Haplodiploidy|haplo-diploid]] system of [[Sex-determination system|sex determination]] makes it possible for the queen to choose the sex of the egg.<ref name=Koedam>Koedam, D., et al. "The Behaviour Of Laying Workers And The Morphology And Viability Of Their Eggs In Melipona Bicolor Bicolor." Physiological Entomology 26.3 (2001): 254-259. Academic Search Premier. Web. 26 Sept. 2015.</ref>
== See also == * [[Cyphopod]]s, sperm receptacles in female millipedes * [[Female sperm storage]] * [[Reproductive system of gastropods]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Animal reproductive system]] [[Category:Sexual anatomy]] [[Category:Animal anatomy]] [[Category:Reproduction]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox sport horse |horsename= Stroller |image= |caption= |breed= [[Thoroughbred]] x [[Connemara pony|Connemara]] |sire= |grandsire= |dam= |damsire= |sex= [[Gelding]] |foaled= 1950 |country= |colour= [[Bay (color)|Bay]], star, near hind sock |breeder= |owner= Marion Mould |trainer= |record= |earnings= |wins= |awards= |honours= |updated= }} {{MedalTableTop|name=Stroller|medals= {{Medal|Sport | [[Equestrianism|Equestrian]]}} {{Medal|Comp|[[Equestrian at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]]}} {{Medal|Silver | [[1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Mexico City]] | [[Equestrian at the 1968 Summer Olympics|Individual jumping]]}} {{Medal|Competition|[[World Equestrian Games|Women's World Championships]]}} {{Medal|Gold|[[Show Jumping World Championships|1965 Hickstead]]|Individual Jumping}} {{Medal|Silver|[[Show Jumping World Championships|1970 Copenhagen]]|Individual Jumping}} }}
'''Stroller''' (1950 - 1986) was a [[Bay (color)|bay]] [[gelding]] who was the only [[pony]] to compete at the [[Olympic Games|Olympics]] in [[show jumping]]. He stood about {{hands|14.1}}.
He was a member of the British team who competed in the [[1968 Summer Olympics|1968 Olympics]] in Mexico, ridden by [[Marion Coakes]]. [[William Steinkraus|Bill Steinkraus]] and Snowbound won the Gold Medal while Marion and Stroller won the Individual Silver Medal, only four faults behind Steinkraus. Stroller jumped one of the only two clear rounds in the Olympic individual championship. In 1967, Marion rode Stroller to victory in the [[All England Jumping Course at Hickstead|Hickstead]] Derby, the only pony to have ever won this event. This partnership won the Wills Hickstead Gold Medal, for points gained in the major events during the year, for five years consecutively from 1965 to 1970. Stroller was the grand age of 20 when he won the 1970 [[Hamburg]] Derby. The pair won 61 international competitions.
He was a crossbred horse, by a [[Thoroughbred]] sire out of a [[Connemara pony]] mare. Stroller died of a heart attack at the high age 36 in 1986, after 15 years of happy retirement. He is buried at [[Barton-on-Sea]] Golf Club, New Milton, Hampshire, England.
==Achievements== * Individual Silver medal at the 1968 Olympic Games ([[Mexico]]) * Winner of the Women's [[Show Jumping World Championships]] 1965 (Hickstead) * Won 1967 Hickstead Derby * Won 1970 Hamburg Derby (as only clear round) * Winner of the Queen Elizabeth II Cup 1965 and 1971 * 2nd place, Women's World Championships 1970 ([[Copenhagen]]) * Only pony to compete at International level among horses and win consistently in Europe * BHS ([[British Horse Society]]) Hall of Fame Laureate
==References== *[http://www.imh.org/imh/bw/conn.html Connemara Pony] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080915015725/http://www.horseandhound.co.uk/competitionnews/390/180623.html Stroller profile in ''Horse & Hound'']

revision.text:
{{about|the activist|the Los Angeles County jail facility named for her|Sybil Brand Institute}} {{Infobox person | name = Sybil Brand | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Sybil Morris{{cite news|last1=McLellan|first1=Dennis|last2=Oliver|first2=Myrna|title=Sybil Brand, 104; Fought for Jailed Women|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/feb/19/local/me-brand19|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=February 19, 2004|page=B10|accessdate=1 November 2015}} | birth_date = {{circa|1899}}{{efn|name=dob|Sources conflict on Brand's year of birth. She had variously stated she was born in 1899 or between 1901 and 1903. Brand's date of birth of record was May 8, 1902.Social Security Death Index, 1935-2014, Ancestry.com.}} | birth_place = [[Chicago, Illinois]] | death_date = {{Death date and given age|2004|02|17|104}}{{cite web|title=Sybil Brand Commission|url=http://sbc.lacounty.gov/#P177_16700|publisher=Los Angeles County|accessdate=September 5, 2014}}{{efn|Based on Brand's recorded 1902 date of birth, she would have been 101 years old when she died.}} | death_place = [[Beverly Hills, California]] | nationality = American | occupation = | known_for = | spouse = Gabriel B. Leavy (December 6, 1926–19??){{cite news|title=Wedding to be Event of March: Angeleno Will Marry Chicago Girl|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=January 23, 1927}}
{{Marriage|[[Harry Brand]]|June 30, 1933|February 22, 1989|end=d}}{{cite news|title=Publicity Man Takes Bride: Couple Fly to Nevada for Ceremony|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=July 1, 1933|page=A12}}{{cite news|last1=Folkart|first1=Burt A.|title=Last of Old-Time Hollywood Press Agents: Ex-Studio Publicist Harry Brand Dies|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-02-23/local/me-246_1_harry-brand|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=February 23, 1989|page=A1}} | children = 1 }} '''Sybil Brand''' (née '''Morris''', {{circa|1899}} – February 17, 2004){{efn|name=dob}} was an American philanthropist and activist, best known locally for her work in improving jail conditions for women in [[Los Angeles]]. She was the namesake of the [[Sybil Brand Institute]] (SBI), a women's jail in [[Los Angeles County]]. SBI was closed after the [[1994 Northridge earthquake]]. ==Early life== Sybil Morris was born in [[Chicago]], Illinois{{cite news|title=Force Behind L.A. Women's Jail Still Going Strong at 80|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/971809/los_angeles_civic_leader_sybil_brand/|work=Santa Cruz Sentinel|agency=Associated Press|volume=127|issue=225|date=September 26, 1983|page=A5|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} to immigrant parents Abraham "A.W." Morris ({{circa|1877}}–1951){{cite news|title=A. W. Morris Family Left $1,000,000|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=August 25, 1951|page=A1}} and Hattie Morris ({{circa|1883}}–1969){{cite news|title=Services Held for Mother of Sybil Brand|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=September 11, 1969|page=C4}} sometime between 1899 and 1903.{{efn|name=dob}} Her father, a stockbroker, relocated the family to Los Angeles when Sybil was two years old.{{USCongRec|1997|E2189|date=November 7, 1997}}. At age twelve, she began what would become a lifelong pursuit of charity and volunteering when she organized a diaper hemming program with the other girls in her class.{{cite news|last1=Baltad|first1=Nancy|title=Playgirl Image Rejected for Credo: 'Help Someone'|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=November 6, 1977|pages=WS1, WS7}} Brand would later recall being inspired by meeting a young triple amputee in a hospital at the insistence of her mother.{{cite news|last1=Savoy|first1=Maggie|title=The Can-Do Lady Who Does It All|work=The Los Angeles Times|date=February 16, 1969|pages=D1, D13}} ==Prison reform== Already well-known in charity circles, Brand was first named to the Public Welfare Commission in 1945 by then-Supervisor Leonard Roach. In the 1950s, Brand was serving on a commission that inspected hospitals and jails in Los Angeles County. The only commissioner to volunteer to inspect the jails, Brand was appalled at the conditions in which women were jailed. At the time, some 1800 women were being held in facilities designed to hold 1300, on the thirteenth floor of the [[Hall of Justice#Los Angeles|Los Angeles Hall of Justice]]. After this incident, Brand led a drive to build a new county jail for women. On January 29, 1963, Los Angeles County opened the Sybil Brand Institute, which was forced to close after the 1994 Northridge earthquake. Budget shortfalls delayed its remodeling and reopening. Women prisoners most recently have been housed in the Twin Towers Correctional Facility in downtown Los Angeles. {{cite news|last1=Duncan|first1=Bill|title=Jail for Women: A Tribute to Sybil Brand|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/971887/sybil_brand_institute_dedicated_back/|work=The Independent Press-Telegram|volume=13|issue=16|date=December 13, 1964|location=Long Beach, California|page=33|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} ==Personal life== In 1926, she married her first husband, Gabriel "Gabe" Leavy in Los Angeles. They had one son, George. In 1933, she married her second husband, Harry Brand, who became head of publicity and advertising at [[20th Century Fox]]. ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Brand, Sybil}} [[Category:Date of birth unknown]] [[Category:Year of birth uncertain]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:American centenarians]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:American human rights activists]]

revision.text:
[[File:CliftonArms.PNG|thumb|220x220px|Arms of Clifton of [[Clifton Hall, Nottingham|Clifton]], Nottinghamshire ([[Baron Clifton]] of [[Leighton Bromswold]]): ''Sable semée of cinquefoils and a lion rampant argent'']] '''Theodosia Bligh, 10th Baroness Clifton''' (9 November 1695{{spaced ndash}}30 July 1722), was an [[England|English]] [[Peerage|peer]], born Theodosia Hyde.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p2930.htm#i29300|title=Person Page|website=www.thepeerage.com|access-date=2018-07-11}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-X4DAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA1196&lpg=PA1196&dq=%22theodosia+hyde%22+bligh&source=bl&ots=kf8rAF0Twz&sig=aYGTo0PM6qKOHM43Cn2WpJqu2_0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ8anC8ZfcAhUJIsAKHWARD244ChDoAQhTMA4#v=onepage&q=%22theodosia%20hyde%22%20bligh&f=false|title=Debrett's Peerage of England, Scotland, and Ireland|last=Debrett|first=John|date=1820|language=en}}</ref>
== Life == [[Baroness]] Clifton was the third child and second daughter of [[Edward Hyde, 3rd Earl of Clarendon]] and [[Katherine Hyde, 8th Baroness Clifton]]. Her mother's title went first to her brother Edward Hyde, 9th Baron Clifton, but after his death from a 'surfeit of drinking',<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thepeerage.com/p2930.htm#i29299|title=Person Page|website=www.thepeerage.com|access-date=2018-07-11}}</ref> she succeeded as the 10th Baroness Clifton, of [[Leighton Bromswold]] on the 12th February 1713.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZrDRAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA248&lpg=PA248&dq=%22theodosia+hyde%22+bligh&source=bl&ots=5YpzuaWLbh&sig=JbAuVKmDMcjmRY5XrUOtlx-PLYQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ8anC8ZfcAhUJIsAKHWARD244ChDoAQhHMAo#v=onepage&q=%22theodosia%20hyde%22%20bligh&f=false|title=England's Topographer: Or A New and Complete History of the County of Kent; from the Earliest Records to the Present Time, Including Every Modern Improvement. Embellished with a Series of Views from Original Drawings by Geo. Shepherd, H. Gastineau, &c. with Historical, Topographical, Critical, & Biographical Delineations|last=Ireland|first=William Henry|date=1830|publisher=G. Virtue|language=en}}</ref>
Baroness Clifton married [[John Bligh, 1st Earl of Darnley]] soon afterwards, on the 24th August 1713 at [[Westminster Abbey]]. They had six children and Baroness Clifton died in childbirth in 1722. She was buried on the 15th August 1722 at [[Westminster Abbey]]. Baroness Clifton's title passed to her second son, [[Edward Bligh, 2nd Earl of Darnley]].
The portrait called "Lady Theodosia Bligh, Countess of Glandore" painted in the manner of John Vanderbank the younger is now thought to be of her mother, Baroness Clifton. It is now in the collection of [[Castle Ward]], [[County Down]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nationaltrustcollections.org.uk/object/836223|title=Called Lady Theodosia Bligh, Countess of Glandore (1722-1777), but really her Mother, Theodosia, Baroness Clifton of Leighton Bromswold, Countess of Darnley (1695-1722) 836223|last=Ltd|first=e3 Media|access-date=2018-07-11|language=en}}</ref>
== Children ==
* Lady Ann Bligh (died 7th February 1789) * Lady Mary Bligh (died 4th March 1791) * George Bligh (died 31st October 1714) * [[Edward Bligh, 2nd Earl of Darnley]] (9th November 1715-22nd July 1747) * [[John Bligh, 3rd Earl of Darnley]] (28th September 1719-31st July 1781) * Lady Theodosia Bligh, Countess of Glandore (1722-20th May 1777)
{{S-start}} {{s-reg|en}} {{succession box | title = [[Baron Clifton|Baroness Clifton]] | years = 1713–1722 | before = [[Edward Hyde, 9th Baron Clifton|Edward Hyde]] | after = [[Edward Bligh, 2nd Earl of Darnley, 11th Baron Clifton|Edward Bligh]] }} {{S-end}}{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Clifton, Theodosia Bligh, 10th Baroness}} [[Category:1695 births]] [[Category:1722 deaths]] [[Category:Barons in the Peerage of England]] [[Category:Hereditary women peers]] [[Category:Clifton family]] [[Category:Deaths in childbirth]] [[Category:Burials at Westminster Abbey]] [[Category:Hyde family (English aristocracy)]]

revision.comment: Link to DAB page repaired
revision.text:
'''Union violence''' is violence committed by unions or union members during labor disputes. When union violence has occurred, it has frequently been in the context of [[industrial unrest]].Philip Taft and Philip Ross, "American Labor Violence: Its Causes, Character, and Outcome," The History of Violence in America: A Report to the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence, ed. Hugh Davis Graham and Ted Robert Gurr, 1969. Violence has ranged from isolated acts by individuals to wider campaigns of organised violence aimed at furthering union goals within an industrial dispute.The Wall Street Journal, November 2, 1990.Michael Gartner, "Nation Shrugs as Thugs Firebomb Freedom," The Wall Street Journal, November 29, 1990.The New York Times, November 15, 1990. [[Anti-union violence]] has also occurred frequently in the context of industrial unrest, and has often involved the collusion of management and government authorities, private agencies, or citizens' groups in organising [[Strikebreaking|violence against unions and their members]].{{cite book |last=Smith|first=Robert Michael|title=From blackjacks to briefcases: a history of commercialized strikebreaking in the United States|year=2003|publisher=Ohio University Press|isbn=978-0-8214-1466-8|pages=xvi-xvii, 179|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s4m963NRvPg|location=Athens OH}}{{cite book |last=Norwood|first=Stephen Harlan|title=Strikebreaking & intimidation: mercenaries and masculinity in twentieth-century America|year=2002|publisher=UNC Press|isbn=978-0-8078-5373-3|page=328|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJJOl7SMWIoC}}{{cite book |title=Union organizing: campaigning for trade union recognition|year=2003|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-26781-6|pages= 79–96|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R8E2E-NxvfcC|first=Gregor|last=Gall|chapter=Employer opposition to union recognition|editor=Gregor Gall|location=London}}{{cite web |title=2010 Annual survey of violations of trade union rights|url=http://survey.ituc-csi.org/+-Whole-World-+.html?lang=en|publisher=International Trade Union Confederation|accessdate=13 June 2010|author=ITUC}}Mixer and server , Volume 12, Hotel and Restaurant Employee's International Alliance and Bartenders' International League of America., 1903, page 44 [[File:Chicago Tribune 1986 strikebreakers.jpg|thumb|200px|Strikebreakers]] ==Overview== Protests and verbal abuse are routinely aimed against union members or replacement workers who cross picket lines ("blacklegs" or "scabs") during industrial disputes. The inherent aim of a union is to create a labor [[monopoly]] so as to balance the [[monopsony]] a large employer enjoys as a purchaser of labor. [[Strikebreaker]]s threaten that goal and undermine the union's bargaining position, and occasionally this erupts into violent confrontation, with violence committed either by, or against, strikers. Some who have sought to explain such violence observe, if labor disputes are accompanied by violence, it may be because labor has no legal redress.J. Bernard Hogg, "Public Reaction to Pinkertonism and the Labor Question," Pennsylvania History 11 (July 1944), 171--199, citing John Bascom, "Civil Law and Social Progress," The Independent, vol. xliv (September 15, 1892), p. 1279. In 1894, some workers declared:
..."the right of employers to manage their own business to suit themselves," is fast coming to mean in effect nothing less than a right to manage the country to suit themselves.J. Bernard Hogg, "Public Reaction to Pinkertonism and the Labor Question," Pennsylvania History 11 (July 1944), 171--199, citing the advisory committee of the Amalgamated Association of Iron and Steel Workers during the Homestead Strike
Occasionally, violent disputes occur between unions, when one union breaks another's strike.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}} ==Research on union violence== Researchers in industrial relations, criminology, and wider cultural studies have examined violence by workers or trade unions in the context of industrial disputes.Rhodri Jeffreys-Jones (1979), Theories of American Labour Violence, Journal of American Studies, 13, pp 245-264, {{doi|10.1017/S0021875800011439}}Armand J. Thieblot, Jr. and Thomas R. Haggard, 1983, Union Violence: The Record and the Response by Courts, Legislatures and the NLRB, Industrial Research Unit, Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania.Brinker, Paul, Violence by U.S. labor unions, Journal of Labor Research, 1985-12-01, Volume 6, Number 4, p. 417-427 US and Australian government reports have examined violence during industrial disputes.Closing the Legal Loophole for Union Violence: Hearing Before the Committee On the Judiciary, United States Senate, One Hundred Fifth Congress, First Session, On S. 230 ... September 3, 1997, Washington: U.S. G.P.O., 1998.{{cite web |author1=Pinto, Susan |author2=Wardlaw, Grant R |url=http://www.aic.gov.au/en/publications/previous%20series/vt/1-9/vt09.aspx |title=Australian Institute of Criminology - Political violence |publisher=Aic.gov.au |date= |accessdate=2011-03-27}} == By country == ===Australia=== * '''1996''' - On 19 August 1996, Australian unionists physically broke into the [[Australian Parliament]] & fought [[Australian Federal Police]] during the [[1996 Parliament House Riot]].{{cite web |url=http://www.aph.gov.au/hansard/senate/dailys/ds200896.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216215833/http://www.aph.gov.au/hansard/senate/dailys/ds200896.pdf |archivedate=2012-02-16 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.anu.edu.au/polsci/marx/interventions/riot.htm |title=Title |publisher=Anu.edu.au |date= |accessdate=2011-03-27}} ===United Kingdom=== * '''1926''' - In the context of the [[1926 United Kingdom general strike]], striking miners derailed [[Flying Scotsman (train)|The Flying Scotsman]] on May 10.http://www.railwaysarchive.co.uk/documents/MoT_AnnitsfordCramlington1926.pdf{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/schools/gcsebitesize/history/mwh/britain/generalstrikerev1.shtml |title=GCSE Bitesize: Chronology of events - the basics |publisher=BBC |date=1926-05-04 |accessdate=2011-03-27}} * '''1972''' - British Trade Union representative [[Ricky Tomlinson]], now best known as an actor, was convicted for a two-year term for threatening construction workers.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-29313261|publisher=BBC |accessdate=2018-07-27}} * '''1984''' - Taxi driver [[Killing of David Wilkie|David Wilkie was killed]] by striking miners while driving a non-striking worker during the [[National Union of Mineworkers (Great Britain)|NUM]] [[UK miners' strike (1984–1985)|UK mining strike of 1984-85]].{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/16/newsid_2512000/2512469.stm |title=BBC ON THIS DAY | 16 | 1985: Miners jailed for pit strike murder |publisher=BBC News |date= May 16, 1985|accessdate=2011-03-27}}Tim Jones, "Miners get life for taxi murder", The Times, 17 May 1985 ===United States=== {{main|Union violence in the United States}} * '''1986''' - During protests by the [[International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers]] Local 1547 against scab labour replacing union jobs, picketers engaged in scuffles, chanting and sounding gunshots.{{cite web |author=Kent Morlan |url=http://www.morelaw.com/verdicts/case.asp?n=S-8207,S-8247&s=AK&d=9236 |title=Alaska Utility Construction Inc. v. International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 1547 |publisher=Morelaw.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-27}}{{cite web |url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/ak-supreme-court/1441305.html |title=Nos. S-8207, S-8247. - INTERNATIONAL BROTHERHOOD OF ELECTRICAL WORKERS LOCAL 1547 v. ALASKA UTILITY CONSTRUCTION INC - AK Supreme Court |publisher=Caselaw.findlaw.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-27}} In 1999, the Alaska Supreme Court ruled that the union had engaged in "ongoing acts of intimidation, violence, destruction of property", awarding the plaintiff $212,500 in punitive damages. * '''1990''' - on the first day of The ''[[New York Daily News]]'' strike, delivery trucks were attacked with stones and sticks, and in some cases burned, with the drivers beaten. Strikers then started threatening newsstands with arson, or stole all copies of the Daily News and burned them in front of the newsstands. James Hoge, publisher of the ''Daily News'', alleged that there had been some 700 serious acts of violence. The New York Police Department claimed knowledge of 229 incidents of violence. Criminal charges under the Hobbs Act were declined, however, citing the aforementioned ''Enmons'' case. * '''1993''' - Eddie York was killed by a rifle shot in the head while crossing a [[United Mine Workers]] (UMW) picket line at a coal mine in Logan County, West Virginia, on July 22, 1993. Like the 1990 NY Daily News strike, criminal charges under the Hobbs Act were declined, with the FBI and Justice Department citing the ''Enmons'' case.{{cite web |url=http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/65/1137/529527/ |title=65 F.3d 1137: United States of America, Plaintiff-appellee, v. Jerry Dale Lowe, Defendant-appellant :: US Court of Appeals Cases :: Justia |publisher=Law.justia.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-27}}Fitzgerald, Randy, "Murder in Logan County", Reader's Digest, Feb. 1995 * '''1997''' - On August 7, 1997, teamsters Orestes Espinosa, Angel Mielgo, Werner Haechler, Benigno Rojas, and Adrian Paez beat, kicked, and stabbed a [[United Parcel Service|UPS]] worker (Rod Carter) who refused to strike, after Carter received a threatening phone call from the home of Anthony Cannestro, Sr., president of Teamsters Local 769.{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/apr/13/business/fi-50418 |title=Beaten UPS Driver Wins Teamsters Settlement - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=1997-08-02 |accessdate=2011-03-27}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nrtw.org/foundation-action/fa_15.htm |title=Foundation Attorneys Sock Teamsters with Racketeering Suit |publisher=NRTW |date= |accessdate=2011-03-27}} ==See also== {{Portal|Organized labour}} * [[Opposition to trade unions]] * [[Labor spies]] * [[Union busting]] '''People''' * [[Norris J. Nelson#Controversies|Norris J.
